abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Private Sector
            Development Project for Ukraine were as follows: the outcome
            was highly unsatisfactory, the sustainability was highly
            unlikely, the institutional development impact was
            substantial, the Bank performance was unsatisfactory, and
            the borrower performance as highly unsatisfactory. Lessons
            learned from the project: Keep the project cycle consistent
            with the opportunity offered by a favorable constituency and
            the project's economic/social relevance in a given
            context. As the economic and political environment changes,
            the Bank needs to adjust fast and effectively, benefiting
            from the flexibility given by operational rules. Building
            ownership for project implementation and project
            sustainability requires broad-based consensus building.

repnme.cdata!: World Bank projects in private sector development

abstracts.cdata!:
Ukraine's European course, declared
            by the supreme state power and supported by society,
            determines the nature of market reforms carried out by the
            Ukrainian Government. This line of reforms is actively
            supported by the World Bank, with its most important
            projects aimed at building up the private sector in Ukraine.
            In 1996 and 1998, the enterprise development adjustment
            loans (EDAL) I and II were implemented in two stages. In
            2002, the World Bank approved granting a loan to Ukraine for
            the private sector development project. This project is a
            systemic (adjustment) type, being oriented not only to the
            extensive development of private enterprises, but also to
            increasing the efficiency and profitability of production,
            and the manufacture of competitive products. The project
            objective is also to ensure that privatized enterprises
            themselves, after acquiring know-how and work experience
            under the conditions of new economic realities, become
            experts and leaders of enterprise restructuring, supporters,
            and implementers of market ideas in the regions.
            Introduction of the latest models of information and
            communication technologies (ICT) can considerably increase
            the efficiency and expeditiousness of decisions approval,
            stimulate the development of the private sector, and
            strengthen civil society in Ukraine. In order to attain
            these goals, a credit agreement on financing the project
            Ukraine: e-development was signed in 2003 between the World
            Bank and the Ukrainian Government. The activities envisaged
            by the project have positive prospects for consolidating
            administrative reform.

5086666.trustfund:
TF035591-ECA REGION - MUNICIPAL FINANCE,TF030465-IRISH CTF FY04 - EASTERN EUROPE,TF036261-UKRAINE - PRIVATE SECTOR
            DEVELOPMENT LOAN,TF041040-UKRAINE - PRIVATE SECTOR
            DEVELOPMENT ADAPTABLE LOAN PROGRAM,TF025596-PHRD-PRIVATE SECTOR DEVELOPMENT PROJECT,TF030454-AUSTRIA GENERAL CTF FY04 - ECA
5086666.majtheme: Financial and private sector development,Rule of law,Public sector governance

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the Private
            Sector Development Project is to increase the
            competitiveness of the Ukraine enterprise sector. There are
            four project components. The first component provides
            advisory services through a local non-profit agency aimed at
            improving the profitability, productivity, and general
            operational, financial, and managerial efficiency of private
            and privatized enteprises; supports and facilitates
            development of a highly qualified domestic consulting
            industry; and strengthens the constituency for reform at the
            oblast level consisting of entrepreneurs, managers, local
            academia, consultants, and other stakeholders. This
            component, which focuses on enterprise restructuring, also
            builds incentives for the government to minimize its
            involvement in the enterprise selection process; for
            stakeholders to maximize cost recovery of consultant
            services; for developing the local consulting market; and
            for foreign consultants to train and mentor local
            consultants. Under the second component, the implementing
            agency will design, subcontract, and supervise in-house
            training courses for selected candidates who, in turn, will
            be required upon completion of their secondment programs, to
            proactively contribute to disseminating their knowledge and
            experience to the business community. The third component
            finances monitoring and project administration. The fourth
            component improves the regulatory environment by providing
            performance-based incentives for deregulation.
